Mahin Chowdhury

Cornell Engineer - Programmer - Game Designer

About Me

I am a passionate problem-solver. I love working with others and demonstrating two main things: my programming skills and my enthusiasm for the adventure. In my head, every project starts with an ambition to make something you didn't know was possible for you before. This mindset has brought me to where I am now — eagerly awaiting my next programming role.

Over the last few years, I have worked on several different teams to build some of my most exciting and rigorous projects. When it comes to the games I've developed, I have worked with other programmers, digital artists, and sound designers to assemble impressive, fun-to-play games. I have also created some useful programs such as a game recommender search engine, a smart traffic light system, and a model depicting the impact of COVID-19.

Smart Traffic Light System

More and more cities are becoming “smart urban infrastructures” that use computing to reduce clutter and improve functionality. One dimension of this is to make the traffic lights at intersections smarter. Rather than having the lights use fixed timing (for example 60s green, then 10s yellow, then 70s red), the city would prefer that green/red periods be variable so that an intersection with lots of cars coming from one side could stay green longer for the busier street.

Game Recommender Search Engine

My partner and I built a full-stack web application that recommends games (board, video, mobile games) based on user searches and filtered preferences. My partner implemented the front end interface, whereas I coded the backend functionality; I used jaccard similarity, cosine similarity, boolean search, edit distance, and sentiment analysis algorithms to generate the results.

Click here to view the project.

Text-Based Pokemon Battle Game

Here, I programmed an interactive-fiction battle game, where users type natural-language commands and the game responds with text. I implemented this using modules, compilation units, and self-coded data types; I also used a large-scale test suite to ensure proper functionality. My favorite part was creating a complex, manually coded game-loop that begins, progresses, and ends the game; this was fun and challenging, considering the other games I made had built-in update functions (in Unity) that looped the game states for me.

Click here to view the project.

The World Starts With You - Platformer Game

I made this video game at the Hack The Mountains 2.0 Hackathon. I collaborated in a team of four (2 programmers, 2 presenters) to build a platform-based video game during a 36-hour coding sprint. I developed and presented this with a meaningful lesson: users are encouraged to be cognizant of the world around them when securing and consuming their needs. I programmed in C# to implement a complex player controller, states, animations, collisions, enemies, collectibles, health system, goal system, player/enemy deaths, sound effects, music, UI, and multiple levels.

Click here to view the project and play the game yourself!

Simeowlation - Endless Runner Game

I made this video game during the GAMERella Global Hackathon. I collaborated in a team of five (2 programmers, 2 artists, 1 musician) to build an infinite-runner video game within 48 hours. I developed and presented this product with the following meaningful lesson: users learn the importance of sticking to a cause no matter what situation or hardship they end up in. We developed all code, art, music, and storyline from scratch. I programmed in C# to implement infinite random object generation, an endlessly running player controller, dynamic winning and losing conditions, states, animations, collisions, enemies, health system, player/enemy deaths, sound effects, music, and UI.

Click here to view the project and play the game yourself!

Modeling the Impact of COVID-19

This visualization shows the spread of COVID-19 and its impacts in the United States from the beginning of the pandemic (March 2020) to November 2021. As the virus continues to spread and disrupt normalcy across the globe, I wanted to visualize where COVID-19 infections have been the highest, and the overall impact on the country; I also wanted to display the deaths and vaccinations over the span of this timeframe to show COVID-19’s impact beyond just the cases. Through this project, I hoped to demonstrate to the reader what states and counties have been affected the most by COVID-19, in terms of number of cases, deaths, and vaccinations.
